1.v: # üöÄ Quick Start Guide: Arweave + AO Development
Welcome to the **Arweave + AO Quick Start Guide**! This guide will help you get up and running as quickly as possible with Arweave‚Äôs **permanent storage** and AO‚Äôs **decentralized compute**.
üè¶ Step 1: Create and Fund Your Wallet (Optional if Done)
To interact with Arweave and AO, you need an **Arweave-compatible wallet**.
If you don‚Äôt have a wallet yet, follow our **[Wallet Creation Guide](./developers/get-started/wallets/create-wallet)** for step-by-step instructions on setting up a Wander Wallet.
Once you have a wallet, you'll need **AR tokens** to pay for transactions. Learn how to acquire and transfer AR tokens in our **[Funding Guide](./developers/get-started/wallets/fund-wallet)**.

For local development and testing, you can use **ArLocal** to simulate the Arweave network without spending real AR tokens. Refer to our **[Local Arweave Setup Guide](./local-arweave-setup.md)** for detailed instructions. -->
## üõ† Step 2: Set Up Your Development Environment
Now that you have your wallet ready, it‚Äôs time to set up your development environment for **building on Arweave and AO**.
üîπ 2.1 Local Arweave Setup (Optional For Testing)
If you haven't set up ArLocal yet, follow our **[Local Arweave Setup Guide](./developers/get-started/installation/arweave)** to create a local testing environment.
Once set up, you can start ArLocal using:
```sh title="Start Local Arweave Node" description="Launches ArLocal for a local Arweave testing environment with instant transactions."
BetterIdea is a **web-based IDE** designed for developing and testing **AO processes** (decentralized applications on AO).
- **Write, test, and deploy AO processes quickly**

Go to the BetterIdea web IDE:
2. Select **Wander Wallet** or another Arweave-compatible wallet
3. You‚Äôll see a Lua script template
Below is a **basic AO message handler** that simply **responds to a received message**:
```lua title="ping-handler.lua" description="A simple AO message handler that replies with a Pong message when it receives 'Ping'."
msg.reply({ Data = "Pong! AO received your message." })
Run the code after you finished pasting/typing it into the block.
#### üöÄ Step 5: Communicating with the AO Process
Now that our AO process is deployed, let's send a message to it using **AO‚Äôs CLI tool** to test the `"Ping-Handler"`.
#### üì° **Step 5.1: Test Your AO Process via BetterIdea CLI**
- In BetterIdea, locate the **CLI Terminal** at the bottom.
2. **Send a Test Message to Your Process**
```sh title="Send AO Message" description="Sends a test message to the deployed AO process using BetterIdea's terminal CLI."
- Replace PROCESS_ID with your actual **deployed AO Process ID** which can be found at the bottom right of the IDE
- If everything is set up correctly, you should see a response:
`New Message From z8H...gz4: Data = Pong! AO received yo`
#### üöÄ Step 6: Setting Up a Vite React TypeScript Project

To interact with **AO and Arweave**, we need a frontend application. **Vite** is a fast build tool for creating modern web applications, and we‚Äôll use it to set up our **React + TypeScript** project.
#### üìå 6.1 Install Vite and Create a New Project
Run the following command in your terminal:
```sh title="Create Vite Project" description="Initializes a new Vite-powered React TypeScript project for AO + Arweave frontend development."
```sh title="Navigate to Project" description="Enter the newly created Vite project directory."
```sh title="Install Dependencies" description="Installs all necessary packages for the React + Vite project."
```sh title="Start Development Server" description="Runs the Vite development server at localhost:5173."
Your Vite app should now be running at [http://localhost:5173](http://localhost:5173) üéâ.
Modify your `"tsconfig.json"` to ensure **strict type-checking** and enable compatibility with **AO libraries**.
Install required packages for interacting with AO:
```sh title="Install aoconnect" description="Installs the @permaweb/aoconnect package to enable AO messaging capabilities."
This package allows us to **communicate with AO processes**.
#### üöÄ Step 6.3: Sending a Dry-Run Message to an AO Process
Now that our **Vite React TypeScript** project is set up, let's send a **dry-run message** to an AO Process.
A **dry-run** allows us to **test AO messaging without requiring a wallet signature**, making development and debugging much faster.
üì° Send a Dry-Run Message to an AO Process
We‚Äôll create a React component that sends a **test message** to an AO Process and displays the response.
```ts title="AOMessage.tsx" description="React component that sends a dry-run message to an AO process and displays the response."
const processId = "YOUR_PROCESS_ID"; // Replace with actual AO Process ID
setResponse(JSON.stringify(res.Messages[0].Data, null, 2)); // Store only the first message from the response
setResponse("Failed to communicate with AO Process.");

üîß Integrating AO Messaging into the Main App
To use our new **AOMessage** component, update `src/App.tsx`:
```ts title="App.tsx" description="Main application entry that renders the AOMessage component on the homepage."
<div className="min-h-screen flex flex-col items-center justify-center bg-black text-white p-6">
üöÄ AO Dry-Run Messaging

This confirms that our frontend **successfully communicates with AO** üéâ.
**Note**: The `dryrun` function is particularly useful for scenarios where immediate feedback is desired without the overhead of permanent storage on the Arweave network.

# üõ†Ô∏è Setting Up Local Arweave with ArLocal

ArLocal is a tool that allows developers to quickly set up a **local Arweave gateway** for testing transactions in a **simulated environment**. This enables you to interact with Arweave without spending AR tokens, making development and testing easier.
Ensure you have **Node.js** and **npm** or **yarn** installed on your machine.
If Node.js is not installed, download it from [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/).
By default, this will start an Arweave gateway on **port 1984**.
You can specify a different port:
#### üìå Option 2: Installing as a Dev Dependency
For persistent usage, install ArLocal as a **dev dependency** in your project:
Then, create a script in your `package.json`:
Now, you can start ArLocal with:
## üîÑ Using ArLocal in a Node.js Script
You can integrate ArLocal into your **Node.js** test environment programmatically:
const arLocal = new ArLocal(); // Create an instance
await arLocal.start(); // Start local Arweave instance
await arLocal.stop(); // Stop ArLocal after testing
const arLocal = new ArLocal(1985, true, "./arlocal_db", true);
## üî¨ Example: Posting a Transaction to ArLocal
// Airdrop AR tokens to the wallet (for local use)
await arLocal.stop(); // Stop ArLocal after testing
‚úÖ **ArLocal provides a local Arweave testing environment**
‚úÖ **Quickly test transactions without spending AR tokens**
‚úÖ **Run with npx or install as a dependency**
‚úÖ **Use Arweave.js to interact with the local instance**
üöÄ **Now you're ready to build & test Arweave applications locally!** üî•

AOS (AO Operating System) is the command-line interface (CLI) and runtime environment for **AO: The Hyper Parallel Computer**. It allows developers to build and interact with AO processes (similar to smart contracts) and leverage AO‚Äôs decentralized compute model.
Before installing **AOS**, ensure you have the following dependencies installed:
To install **AOS**, run the following command:
After running `aos` for the first time, it installs itself on your machine.
Next time, you can simply run:
If you want to build AOS from source or modify it, follow these steps:
In AOS, **Processes** are like smart contracts that execute code. You can create and interact with these processes using the CLI.
To create a new AO Process:
Once a process is created, you can start interacting with it by running:
AOS supports various flags to customize how a process runs:
| `--relay [Relay URL]`   | Enables payment processing via HyperBEAM relay |
| `--cron [Interval]`     | Executes the process at specified intervals (e.g., `10-minutes`, `5-hours`, `10-blocks`) |
| `--get-blueprints [dir]` | Loads predefined **Lua scripts** (blueprints) into the process |
| `--load [luaFile]`      | Loads a Lua script from a local file |
| `--sqlite`              | Uses SQLite module for local storage within AOS |
| `--tag-name [name]` `--tag-value [value]` | Adds metadata tags to the process |
## üìú 6. Deploying a Process with Boot Scripts
AOS allows you to **auto-run Lua scripts** when a process starts. You can do this by setting the `On-Boot` tag.
### **7.1 Setting Up AOS for Advanced Development**
If you're modifying the AOS runtime, you may need to rebuild the WebAssembly (WASM) module:
After deploying, copy the **module ID** and update your `package.json` or `README.md`.
### üéâ Now you are ready to run **AOS** and start building decentralized applications using **AO: The Hyper Parallel Computer!** üöÄ
# üöÄ Deploy Your AO + React App to Arweave with ArLink
You‚Äôve built your app ‚Äî now it‚Äôs time to **go live** on the **permaweb** using [Arweave](https://www.arweave.org) and **ArLink**.

**Arweave** isn't just for storing images or files; it can also host your **entire application permanently**. However, specific configurations are necessary to ensure your app works correctly on the permaweb.

Arweave operates as a decentralized storage network without traditional server-side routing. This means client-side routing configurations (e.g. `HashRouter`) are crucial. Without them, users may encounter broken links or refresh errors.
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Wallet Must Have AR Tokens
To deploy your app, your wallet **must contain AR tokens**. These are used to pay for storage. Without AR tokens, deployment **will fail**.
You can deploy your app in **two ways**:
üåê Option 1: Use the ArLink Web Interface
You can deploy via the **no-code UI** at:
> If you're used to deploying apps with Vercel, this will feel right at home ‚Äî simple, clean, and developer-friendly.
For a step-by-step guide, follow the official ArLink docs:
üß± Option 2: Local CLI + ArNS (Advanced)
This method uses **ArNS** (Arweave Name System), a decentralized naming system for Arweave.
3. Click which wallet account you want to use to deploy your application.
üö´ **DO NOT COMMIT THIS FILE** ‚Äî add `.secrets/` to your `.gitignore`
<pre><code class="language-sh" title="scripts/deploy.sh" description="Shell script to deploy your dist/ folder to Arweave using ArNS and permaweb-deploy.">
echo "dist directory does not exist. Please build the project first"
echo "UNDERNAME is not set. Setting it to arweb"
To obtain your ArNS name, visit the ArNS dashboard, which would be the Process ID of the asset. You will need to either rent or buy an ArNS name.
Update the `--ant-process` value in the script to your ArNS name:
Update the `--undername` value in the script to your desired ArNS name (this can be anything you choose):
You‚Äôll get a live URL like:
You can link a custom domain to your Arweave deployment using TXT records.
- ‚úÖ Share your live link on [AO Discord](https://discord.gg/arweave)

Wander is a popular Arweave-compatible wallet that allows you to interact with **decentralized applications (dApps)** and manage digital assets on the **Arweave and AO networks**. Follow this guide to set up your **Wander wallet**.
## üõ† Step 1: Install the Wander Browser Extension
- Visit the official Wander extension page:
- Click **"Add to Chrome"** and confirm any installation prompts.
- Once installed, the Wander icon will appear in your browser toolbar.
1. Click on the **Wander** extension icon in your browser toolbar.
4. Wander will generate a **12-word seed phrase**.
5. **Write it down** and store it in a **secure location**.
6. **DO NOT** share this phrase with anyone. It is the only way to recover your wallet.
7. **Confirm the seed phrase** by entering it in the correct order.
8. Set a **strong password** that will be used to unlock your wallet.
9. Follow the rest of the prompts.
10. Congratulations! Your account is finally created!
5. Set a **strong password** that will be used to unlock your wallet.
üéâ **Congratulations!** You‚Äôve successfully created your Wander wallet and are now ready to explore the Arweave and AO ecosystems with your new digital assets!
## üöÄ Step 3: Access and Manage Your Wallet
Once setup is complete, you will be redirected to the **Wander Dashboard**, where you can:
To interact with the Arweave and AO ecosystems using your Wander wallet, you'll need to acquire **AR tokens**. Here's a step-by-step guide to help you fund your wallet.
**AR tokens** are the native cryptocurrency of the Arweave network. You can purchase them through various cryptocurrency exchanges. Here's how:
Select a reputable exchange that supports AR token trading. Some popular exchanges include:
- Sign up on the chosen exchange and complete any necessary verification processes.
- Add funds to your exchange account using your preferred payment method (e.g., bank transfer, credit card).
- Navigate to the trading section and buy the desired amount of AR tokens.
## üè¶ Step 2: Transfer AR Tokens to Your Wander Wallet
After purchasing AR tokens, transfer them to your Wander wallet:
- Launch the Wander extension or mobile app.
- Locate and copy your unique wallet address. This is typically found under the "Receive" section.
- In your exchange account, go to the withdrawal section.
- Enter the amount of AR tokens to transfer.
- Blockchain transactions may take some time. Once confirmed, your AR tokens will appear in your Wander wallet.
For more detailed instructions and support, refer to Wander's official help articles:
- [How to buy AR tokens with fiat currency](https://www.wander.app/help/browser-extension-how-to-buy-ar-tokens-with-a-fiat-currency)
**Note:** Ensure you're sending AR tokens to the correct wallet address. Transactions on the blockchain are irreversible.

In the evolving landscape of **digital ownership and decentralized storage**, Atomic Assets emerge as a **groundbreaking solution**. Built on **Arweave**, they integrate **data, metadata, and licensing** into a **single immutable identifier**.
An **Atomic Asset** is a **digital package** that consolidates:
Unlike **traditional NFTs**, which often rely on **off-chain storage**, Atomic Assets ensure:
- **Multiple users to own portions** of a single asset.
- **Seamless buying, selling, and trading** within the asset itself.
- **No reliance on third-party platforms** for ownership validation.
Atomic Assets utilize the **Universal Data License (UDL)**:

Atomic Assets **redefine digital content ownership** by ensuring **permanence, fractional ownership, and clear licensing**. As **NFTs evolve**, Atomic Assets stand as the **next-generation standard** for **secure and immutable digital assets**.
Atomic Assets represent a **significant advancement in digital assets**, addressing the **limitations of traditional NFTs** by:
- **Facilitating fractional ownership** (multiple owners can hold stakes).
As the digital landscape evolves, Atomic Assets provide a **reliable foundation** for creators seeking **permanence, security, and clear ownership**.
The **Universal Data License (UDL)** offers **creators full control** over **usage, licensing, and monetization** of digital assets.
- Decide if **content can be used** for **AI training** or **data models**.
1. **Attach a UDL license** to digital assets.
The **UDL empowers creators** by **providing legal clarity, monetization options, and full control** over digital content.
The **Universal Data License (UDL)** is a **standardized framework** that enables **content creators** to:
- **Define usage terms** (commercial use, modifications, derivative works).
- **Monetize digital assets** via **one-time fees, subscriptions, or pay-per-access models**.
By leveraging **decentralized storage on Arweave**, the **UDL ensures long-term protection** for **creators & their intellectual property**.

Arweave is a groundbreaking **decentralized storage protocol** designed to provide **permanent data storage solutions**.

Unlike traditional storage systems that require recurring payments and are susceptible to data loss or censorship, Arweave offers a unique **"pay once, store forever"** model. This approach ensures that **data remains immutable and perpetually accessible**, revolutionizing how information is preserved in the digital age.
At the core of Arweave's architecture is the **blockweave**, an innovative data structure that differentiates it from conventional blockchains:
- Traditional blockchains form a linear sequence.
- Arweave's **blockweave links each block to both the previous block and a randomly selected earlier block**.
- This enhances **data redundancy** and plays a key role in the network‚Äôs **Proof of Access (PoA)** consensus mechanism.
When users upload data, they **pay a one-time fee in AR tokens**:
- A portion is allocated to a **storage endowment**.
- The endowment generates **returns to compensate miners**, ensuring **data remains available indefinitely**.
Arweave fosters a **community-driven ecosystem** where developers can build:
- **Gateways** that provide seamless access to stored data.
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
Arweave is a decentralized protocol designed for **permanent data storage**, allowing users to preserve information indefinitely with a single, one-time fee.
Secured by a network of **miners rewarded with AR tokens**, Arweave ensures data is replicated and remains accessible through a **sustainable endowment model**.

This approach supports the **permaweb**‚Äîa collection of permanent web pages and applications **free from centralized control**, fostering a space where **history and culture are preserved**, and **free speech is upheld**.
Developers are empowered to create **fully decentralized applications** on the permaweb, contributing to a more **resilient and open internet**.
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
The **permaweb** is a revolutionary concept **built on top of Arweave**, creating a **decentralized and immutable web**.
Unlike the **traditional internet**, which is **vulnerable to data loss**, the permaweb ensures that once information is uploaded, it **is stored forever**.
- The traditional web relies on **centralized servers**, meaning data can be **lost if a server shuts down**.
- The permaweb distributes content **across a global network of nodes**.
## **What Can Be Built on the Permaweb?**
Beyond static files, developers can create **full-fledged decentralized applications (dApps)** that:
- **Gateways** ‚Üí Act as access points for retrieving and displaying stored data.
- **GraphQL APIs** ‚Üí Enable users to efficiently query stored data.
- **Profit-Sharing Communities (PSCs)** ‚Üí Allow developers to distribute revenue and governance to users.
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
The **permaweb** is a **permanent, decentralized web** built on Arweave. It **eliminates broken links and missing content**, ensuring that data and applications remain **permanently accessible**.
Beyond simple **file storage**, the permaweb hosts **full-fledged decentralized applications** that:
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
One of the biggest challenges in **blockchain-based storage solutions** is **scalability**. Arweave tackles this challenge through **unique innovations** that allow it to scale indefinitely.
Unlike **contract-based storage systems** that require complex verification, Arweave applies a **single set of rules**:
- **"Pay once, store forever"** ‚Üí Eliminates the need for constant payment models.
- **All transactions follow the same storage principles**, reducing processing complexity.
Instead of processing transactions individually, Arweave allows:
- **Multiple transactions to be combined into a single bundle**.
This process is governed by the **Arweave Network Standard -104**, ensuring efficiency.
When too many transactions are submitted, **recursive bundling** is used:
- **Bundles are combined into larger bundles before submission**.
- This allows an **unlimited number of transactions** in a single Arweave operation.
Arweave‚Äôs **storage model assumes costs will decrease over time**, making it:
- **More efficient than traditional cloud storage solutions**.
- [How Arweave Scales: Storing All the Data on the Web](https://arweave.org/)
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
Arweave achieves **scalability** through several key innovations:
- **Transaction bundling** ‚Üí Multiple transactions are combined into a single block, improving efficiency.
- **Blockweave structure** ‚Üí Uses a **Proof of Access (PoA) consensus** to ensure redundancy.
- **Recursive bundling** ‚Üí Transactions can be **bundled within bundles**, enabling **theoretical infinite scalability**.
These innovations make Arweave a **robust solution for decentralized, permanent data storage**.
- [How Arweave Scales: Storing All the Data on the Web](https://arweave.org/)
- [Arweave for Newbies: How It Works and Why It Exists](https://x.com/onlyarweave/status/1805983704549929286)
AO is a **decentralized compute platform** built on Arweave that introduces a **revolutionary way to process and execute computations at scale**.
Unlike traditional **cloud or blockchain systems**, which have **limited processing power**, AO uses **hyper-parallel computing**, allowing **unlimited simultaneous tasks**.
- Support complex applications such as **AI models, validator nodes, and dApps**.
- **Integrates with Arweave for permanent data storage**.
- **Artificial Intelligence (AI)** ‚Üí Train and run AI models in a decentralized environment.
- **Decentralized Finance (DeFi)** ‚Üí Supports on-chain validation and smart contract execution.
AO is a **decentralized hyper-parallel compute** layer built on **Arweave**.

1.v: One of AO‚Äôs defining features is its ability to **scale infinitely through parallel execution**. Unlike traditional blockchain systems that rely on **sequential execution**, AO enables **modular and on-demand computation**.
AO functions as a **distributed supercomputer**, running **countless computations simultaneously**.
- **No global state** ‚Üí Each process retrieves only the data it needs.
AO messages follow a structured workflow:
2. **Scheduler Unit (SU)** ‚Üí Orders messages and stores them permanently on Arweave.
3. **Compute Unit (CU)** ‚Üí Processes messages and executes logic.
This ensures **high throughput** while maintaining **decentralized security**.
With its **hyper-parallel design**, AO is well-suited for:
- **Web3 & Smart Contracts** ‚Üí Runs complex smart contracts efficiently.
- **Decentralized AI** ‚Üí Handles AI training & model execution.
- **Onchain Virtual Worlds** ‚Üí Powers interactive, persistent metaverse environments.
AO achieves **infinite scalability** by executing tasks **in parallel**.
- **Modular, on-demand computation** ‚Üí No shared global state.
- **Dynamic Compute Expansion** ‚Üí More Compute Units (CUs) can be added as needed.
This makes AO **ideal for Web3, AI, and high-performance onchain applications**.
## üöÄ How is Arweave + AO Different from Traditional Full-Stack Applications?
| Feature            | Traditional Full-Stack Apps | Arweave + AO The Computer |
| **Storage**       | Relies on centralized databases (SQL, NoSQL, Firebase, AWS, etc.) | Uses Arweave‚Äôs **permanent** decentralized storage with a "pay once, store forever" model |
| **Compute**       | Uses centralized servers (AWS, DigitalOcean, Vercel, etc.) | AO provides **decentralized, parallelized execution** for smart contracts & compute tasks |
| **Data Ownership** | Controlled by corporations, prone to censorship | **Immutable & permissionless**, controlled by users |
| **Scalability**   | Limited by server infrastructure | **Infinite scalability** with decentralized compute units |
| **Security**      | Server hacks and data loss risks | **Trustless & censorship-resistant**, no single point of failure |
- **No servers:** You don‚Äôt need AWS, Firebase, or Vercel. Everything is **on-chain**.
- **Immutable Storage:** Unlike centralized databases, **Arweave permanently stores** your data.
- **Decentralized Compute:** AO acts like a **Web3 CPU**, running decentralized processes in parallel.

## ‚ö° How is Arweave + AO Different from Other Web3 Ecosystems?
| Feature            | Ethereum / Solana / Polygon | Arweave + AO The Computer |
| **Storage**       | Uses IPFS/Filecoin (temporary, unreliable) | **Arweave stores data permanently** with no expiration |
| **Smart Contracts** | Runs on Ethereum/Solana (gas fees, limited compute) | **AO provides infinitely scalable compute** with parallel processing |
| **Execution Model** | Sequential transactions (slow, expensive gas fees) | **Parallel execution** for near-instant processing |
| **Scalability**   | L2 solutions required (Optimism, Arbitrum) | **Native horizontal scaling** via AO Compute Units |
| **Interoperability** | Limited to EVM-based chains | **AO can run smart contracts & dApps for multiple chains** |
- **Arweave is the only blockchain with **permanent storage** (others use temporary IPFS).**
- **AO brings parallel compute**, removing blockchain limitations like high gas fees.
- **Unlike Ethereum, AO scales infinitely without Layer 2 solutions.**

How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Hosting & Backend** | Uses centralized cloud providers (AWS, Firebase, Vercel) | Some decentralized hosting (IPFS, Filecoin) but limited permanence | Fully decentralized hosting & compute (Arweave + AO) |

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Storage**          | Databases like PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Firebase (data can be altered/deleted) | Uses IPFS/Filecoin (but requires pinning to keep data accessible) | **Arweave provides permanent, immutable storage** |

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Compute Execution** | Runs on centralized servers (Node.js, Python, Go, etc.) | Smart contracts execute on-chain (Ethereum/Solana) but limited in scope | **AO enables scalable, parallel, decentralized execution** |

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Smart Contracts**  | Uses Node.js, Python, Express for API logic | Solidity (Ethereum), Rust (Solana) | **AO uses Lua for execution, SmartWeave for contract logic** |

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Databases**        | SQL (PostgreSQL, MySQL), NoSQL (MongoDB, Firebase) | Indexed event logs, IPFS/Filecoin for partial data storage | **Databases can be written inside AO (currently SQLite3)** |

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: | **Frontend & Routing** | Uses Next.js, Vite, traditional SSR/CSR models | Same frameworks, but relies on blockchain nodes for querying | **Same frontend stack (Next.js, Vite, React)**, routing works differently (Arweave gateways instead of servers) |

How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: - **Frontend development stays the same** ‚Üí You still use Next.js, Vite, TailwindCSS, etc.

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: - **Routing system differs** ‚Üí Since Arweave stores content permanently, it uses gateways instead of standard API-based routing.

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: - **No backend servers needed** ‚Üí Instead of Express.js, FastAPI, or Node-based backends, AO acts as the backend & middleware.

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: - **AO uses Lua** for execution ‚Üí If you need complex logic, AO replaces the backend with **Lua-based compute**.

0.v: How Applications Built on Arweave + AO differ

1.v: - **Databases inside AO** ‚Üí Instead of Firebase/PostgreSQL, you can write **SQLite3 databases inside AO**.
